Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Shawn M. Billerman

Proposal number 1612277

This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Shawn M. Billerman is "Specimen-based comparisons of hybridization: the effect of genetic and environmental forces on hybrid zones in a suture zone." The host institution for this fellowship is Cornell University and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Irby Lovette.

The goal of this research is to explore how genetic and environmental mechanisms influence speciation in suture zones. Hybrid zones are places where the ranges of two previously isolated populations of two different species overlap, where the two species interbreed. These areas of active hybridization are often regarded as natural laboratories in which to study speciation. While studies of single hybrid zones have improved our understanding of evolutionary processes, we can better test for the general factors that contribute to the creation of biodiversity by investigating and comparing multiple hybrid zones. Suture zones, where multiple hybrid zones cluster in geographic space, represent particularly powerful opportunities to identify the shared environmental and genetic mechanisms that contribute to speciation. The Fellow is comparing patterns of hybridization across five different pairs of bird species that meet and hybridize in the Great Plains of North America. Using historical bird specimens in the Cornell University Museum of Vertebrates, the Fellow is investigating how different conditions affect speciation through time. This comparative approach combines studying movement of genes across hybrid zones, how plumage traits are distributed across the landscape relative to the genetic background of each species pair, and how past changes in climate have affected changes in the distributions of each hybrid zone over time. The Fellow is leveraging a unique series of hybrid zone specimens collected in the 1950s and 60s that allow for comparison and identification of the mechanisms regulating suture zone dynamics at an unprecedented scale and level of detail.

The Fellow is receiving training in the extraction of genetic material from museum specimens, and learning new analytical skills for using extremely large, genome-wide datasets. In particular, the Fellow is learning how to assemble whole-genome sequence data and develop tools to identify genomic regions of particular importance for speciation and biodiversity. He is also developing outreach material for the public by leveraging the resources of project eBird, an NSF funded citizen science program run by the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, to educate the public about how studying hybridization can help reveal the impact of climate change on biodiversity. The Fellow is also developing educational modules for the Cornell Lab of Ornithology that emphasize the value of studying hybrid zones and hybridization. Finally, the Fellow is mentoring undergraduate researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hybrid zones—locations where two previously isolated populations come into secondary contact and interbreed—are often regarded as natural laboratories that can provide powerful insights into the differences that contribute most to reproductive isolation between taxa. While studies of hybrid zones at a single point in time are important and informative, comparisons across multiple time points, and across multiple different hybrid zones, help us to understand how mechanisms that contribute to reproductive isolation change over time, and how they may influence speciation on a broader geographic scale. The Great Plains of North America is a particularly well-known and well-studied region where 5 pairs of avian taxa hybridize extensively. Part of what makes the Great Plains hybrid zones particularly powerful to study are the data we have: all of these hybrid zones are represented by incredible series of specimens from the 1950s and 1960s that provide important benchmarks for understanding how hybrid zones have changed over time. In addition to historical museum samples, recent collecting trips that have sampled these same hybrid zones, in combination with citizen science data, has allowed us to understand what shared mechanisms may be important in maintaining reproductive isolation across multiple hybrid zones.

I used an integrative approach that includes genetic data sampled from historical museum specimens to understand patterns of genetic introgression. I used a unique series of museum specimens housed at the Cornell University Museum of Vertebrates (CUMV), which includes historical specimens from the Eastern Towhee (Pipilo erythrophthalmus) and Spotted Towhee (P. maculatus) hybrid zone, and historical specimens from the Baltimore Oriole (Icterus galbulus) and Bullock’s Oriole (I. bullockii) hybrid zone. To sample genetic data from historical specimens, I used a new approach called hyRAD, hybrid capture using RAD probes, which is particularly well suited for sequencing degraded DNA from museum specimens. Analysis of the towhee hybrid zone suggests that there is extensive hybridization across a relatively wide area of the Great Plains, with most individuals from the hybrid zone showing evidence of mixed ancestry. Contrary to the towhees, preliminary analysis of the historical oriole hybrid zone suggests relatively little hybridization, with hybrid individuals restricted to a fairly narrow region in the Great Plains. By characterizing the genetic structure of each of these hybrid zones in detail, and by assessing the concordance of different genetic patterns within each hybrid zone, we can better understand the relative contribution of intrinsic, lineage-specific selection pressures to hybrid zone maintenance.

In addition to studying patterns of genetic introgression, I also studied the role that climate plays in patterns of past and current hybridization. Environmental conditions often strongly influence where divergent taxa meet in secondary contact and form hybrid zones. To develop a comprehensive model that describes the influence of climate on maintaining the structure of the different hybrid zones of the Great Plains, I combined museum specimen data with data from the citizen science project, eBird. While climate was able to predict the distributions of each hybrid zone with high support, I found that different sets of climate conditions were important for different hybrid zones, contrary to my predictions. Further, I also found that over time not all hybrid zones tracked changes in climate in the same way, suggesting that climate may not be the main factor influencing hybrid zone position and maintenance over time in the Great Plains. In particular, I found that the towhee hybrid zone did not appear to track changes in climate, while the oriole hybrid zone did track changes in climate over time. These differences suggest different selection pressures between these systems and may help us better understand how and why these hybrid zones are maintained.

Over the course of the postdoc, I also had the opportunity to present my research at many conferences, where I was able to highlight some of the novel approaches I used to study hybridization using museum specimens. This has led to fruitful collaborations and discussions on the best ways to use historical museum specimens in genetic studies. In addition to presenting at conferences, I also developed a project in collaboration with an undergraduate at Cornell University. This project has involved measuring museum specimens to understand patterns of selection across hybrid zones, which ultimately may help us to better understand how each hybrid zone is maintained over time. This has developed into a fruitful research project, and the student has been active in all aspects, and she has taken the lead role in writing the manuscript that will be published on this research.
